def.dt: :a structure built over something (such as a river) so that people or vehicles can get across a bridge connecting the island to the mainland the Brooklyn Bridge a railroad bridge [=a bridge for trains] see also drawbridge footbridge suspension bridge

:something that joins or connects different people or things Her work serves as a bridge between the past and the present. They hope to build a bridge between the two cultures. [=they hope to help the people in the two cultures understand each other]
:the place on a ship where the ship is steered
:the upper part of the nose He broke the bridge of his nose.
:the part of a pair of eyeglasses that rests on a person's nose
:the part of a guitar, violin, or similar musical instrument that raises the strings away from the surface
:part of a song that connects one section to the next section
:a false tooth or row of false teeth that fits between two real teeth

dro.dre: cross that bridge when you come to it

dt.snote: If you say you will cross that bridge when you come to it, you mean that you will not worry about a possible problem until it actually happens. I don't know how we'll pay the bills if you quit your job, but we'll cross that bridge when we come to it.

def.dt: :to make a bridge over or across (something) usually used figuratively We hope to bridge the divisions between the two groups. often used in the phrase bridge the gap styles that bridge the gap between fashion and practicality a book that attempts to bridge the generation gap
:a card game for four players in two teams
:money that a bank lends you for a short period of time until you receive the money that you are getting from another source (such as from selling your house) called also (Brit) bridging loan
:a bridge that is hung from two or more cables that are held up by towers
:a bridge that can be moved or raised so that tall boats can pass under it

:to go from one side of (something) to the other :to go across (something) + obj We crossed the state border hours ago. The dog crossed the street. The highway crosses the entire state. He was the first runner to cross the finish line. no obj The train crosses through France.
:to go or pass across each other no obj the point at which two lines cross [=intersect] Put a nail where the boards cross. + obj One line crossed the other.

:to place one arm, leg, etc., over the other cross your arms/legs/fingers If you cross your fingers or keep your fingers crossed, you hope that you will be lucky and that something you want to happen will happen. I crossed my fingers and hoped that I would be chosen. Keep your fingers crossed. I just sent out my college applications.
:to draw a line across (something) Remember to cross your t's. [=to put a line across the top of the letter “t” when you write it] see also dot your i's and cross your t's at dot
:to pass in opposite directions Our letters crossed in the mail. [=my letter was going to you while your letter was coming to me]
:to turn (your eyes) inward toward your nose He crossed his eyes.
:to act against the wishes, plans, or orders of (someone) My boss is usually nice, but she has a terrible temper and you don't want to cross her. see also double-cross star-crossed

:to make two different kinds of animals breed together The breeders crossed [=crossbred, interbred] the bison with domestic cattle. often used figuratively to describe someone or something that combines the qualities of two different people or things As our leader, she was like a drill sergeant crossed with a camp counselor.
:to mix two kinds of plants to form a new one The farmers crossed two different types of corn together.
:to kick or hit the ball sideways across the field + to He crossed to his teammate.

dt.snote: The phrases cross my heart or cross my heart and hope to die are used in informal speech to stress that you are telling the truth and will do what you promise. I'll clean my room tomorrow—cross my heart. [=I promise that I'll clean my room tomorrow]

def.dt: :to draw a line through (a name or item on a list) They crossed off the names of the people who had already been invited. We can cross her off our list of potential donors.
:to draw a line through (something) to show that it is wrong cross out a mistake
:to move or go from one side of (something) to the other The deer crossed over to the other side of the river. The bridge crosses over the river.

:to change from one type of character or condition to another People were crossing over to vote for the other party's candidate. [=people in one political party were voting for the other party's candidate] The singer crossed over from country to pop. [=the singer changed his style of music from country to pop] see also crossover

dt.snote: When people cross paths or when their paths cross, they meet each other at a time that was not planned or expected. After they left college, it was many years before they crossed paths again. = It was many years before their paths crossed again. I crossed paths with an old friend on a business trip.

def.dt: :to appear briefly on someone's face A smile crossed her face.
:to come into someone's mind :to be thought of by someone Losing never crossed her mind. [=she was sure that she would win] Did it ever cross your mind that I could be right?
:to fight or argue often + with I didn't want to cross swords with him about who was right.

dro.dre: cross that bridge when you come to it

def.dt: :to go beyond what is proper or acceptable Her criticism crossed the line from helpful to just plain hurtful. The magazine crossed the line when they printed the nude photos.
:to make (someone) confused The team crossed up their opponent by throwing the ball instead of running it.
:to ruin (something) completely His failure to meet the deadline crossed up the deal.
:to make the sign of the cross on your head and chest I crossed myself as I entered the church.

:the clear liquid that has no color, taste, or smell, that falls from clouds as rain, that forms streams, lakes, and seas, and that is used for drinking, washing, etc. Would you like a glass of water? bottled/mineral/spring water There's water dripping from the ceiling. Drink some water. drinking water [=water that is safe for drinking] The house has hot and cold running water. [=water carried by pipes inside a building] see also bathwater freshwater groundwater holy water ice water mineral water rainwater rose water saltwater seawater soda water tap water toilet water white water

:an area of water (such as a lake, river, or ocean) deep/shallow water The kids love playing in the water. A stick was floating on/in the water. They like to vacation near the water. see also underwater
:a specific area of water

:an area of seawater frigid northern waters coastal/shallow waters We are sailing in international waters. They were fishing in Canadian waters. often used figuratively We are entering into dangerous waters [=a difficult or complicated situation] whenever we discuss religion in public. He began studying the murky waters [=confusing details] of copyright law. The company is moving into uncharted waters [=new and unknown areas] with its Internet marketing campaign. see also headwaters territorial waters
:methods of travel that involve boats and ships They came by water. [=by traveling on a boat or ship]
:to be possible or believable usually used in negative statements Her argument doesn't hold water. [=does not make sense] His theory cannot hold water. [=his theory is wrong]
:in large amounts He spends money like water.
:to send urine out of the body :urinate a patient who is finding it difficult to pass water

:to say that you do not like (an idea, suggestion, etc.) in a way that stops other people from doing it or from feeling enthusiastic about it He wanted to buy a new car, but I poured/threw cold water on that idea. [=I said he should not buy a new car]

dt.un: used to describe what happens when fluid suddenly comes from a pregnant woman's body because her baby will be born soon Her water broke early.

dt.snote: If something, such as criticism, advice, etc., is (like) water off a duck's back, it has no effect on someone. He tried to convince her to take the job, but his advice was like water off a duck's back. [=she completely ignored his advice]

dt.un: used to say that something happened in the past and is no longer important or worth arguing about We had our differences in the past, but that's all water under the bridge now.
